cm3038.search
Interface State

public interface State

This interface defines the methods required on a problem state. Any class that represents a problem state must implement this interface.

Author:
Kit-ying Hui

Method Summary
 boolean equals(java.lang.Object state)
          Checks if two states are equal.
 int hashCode()
          Calculate the hash code of a state.
 java.util.List<ActionStatePair> successor()
          This is the successor function which generates all action-states of a state when it is expanded.
 java.lang.String toString()
          Converts the state into a String.
 

Method Detail

toString

java.lang.String toString()
Converts the state into a String. This method controls how a state will be printed.

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
A String representation of the state.

equals

boolean equals(java.lang.Object state)
Checks if two states are equal. This is required as we need to check for repeated states in the history. They may be 2 different State objects but if they represent the same state (i.e. same attribute values), then they are equal. If you get this wrong for your State class, the search may fall into an infinite loop (as it cannot tell if a state is being repeated).

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
state - The other state to compare with.
Returns:
true if the current state and the other are the same (value-wise). false otherwise.

hashCode

int hashCode()
Calculate the hash code of a state. This method is needed because internally we are using a HashSet to store the history (of states), and the Set.contains(Object) method of the HashSet to check if a state is in the history. For this to work correctly in Java, the object (i.e. State) to be stored into the HashSet must have a int hashCode() method defined. Objects which are equal (e.g. all attribute values are the same) must have the same hash code. The hash code is usually calculated based on the attribute values of the object.

Overrides:
hashCode in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
The hash code of the State object.

successor

java.util.List<ActionStatePair> successor()
This is the successor function which generates all action-states of a state when it is expanded. This method must be tailored for each domain. The returned result is a List of ActionStatePair objects. It is a list, not a set as we want to keep the order of the children nodes. If use a Set, the order is not kept/guaranteed.

Returns:
All possible action-state pairs as a List of ActionStatePair objects.
